channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: Meet The Ultimate Endurance Athlete
item.description: Kilian Jornet Burgada is the most dominating endurance athlete of his generation. He has run across entire landmasses­ (Corsica) and mountain ranges (the Pyrenees), nearly without pause. He regularly runs all day eating only wild berries and drinking only from streams.

item.title: Why Did Apple Hire A Guy Who Once Ran Over An iPhone With A Steam Roller?
item.description: Just hours after word leaked that Apple had poached Adobe's chief technology officer, the Internet is ablaze with the question of what, exactly, the iPhone maker plans to do with Kevin Lynch.

item.title: Here Is President Obama Speaking Hebrew For Three Seconds
item.description: As he began a three-day trip to Israel, the West Bank, and Jordan today, President Obama delighted his hosts by speaking stilted Hebrew for three seconds during a speech on the tarmac at Tel Aviv's airport.

item.title: Never Lose Your Photos – Or Videos – Again
item.description: Remember how Picturelife makes backing up and showing all your photos as easy as taking them? Yeah, well now they're doing the same with video, no matter the file size. If you haven't given them a shot, here's your chance.

item.title: The Complete Guide To Taking Notes Effectively At Work
item.description: Here’s everything you need to know about taking notes at work, but never bothered to ask.

item.title: The Problem With Google, As Seen Through Its NCAA Bracket
item.description: Here’s the current state of things. If you search for “NCAA bracket”, Google pops up a March Madness bracket with the full schedule. It’s not even using a sidebar at this point and is only showing the bracket.

item.title: Watch A Drone Fly Between Two Tesla Coils
item.description: Here's a drone flying between two tesla coils.

item.title: Hilarious Notes On Modern Classics From Clueless Studio Executives
item.description: The image of non-creative types mucking about with (and screwing up) movies and television shows is nothing new — we’ve seen it in everything from Barton Fink to The Player to The Larry Sanders Show. Here are a few real life examples.

item.title: The Greatest MIT Hacks Of All-Time
item.description: MIT is the birthplace of the hacker. Back in the science-loving 1950s, MIT's Tech Model Railroad club developed the ethos that would help drive the evolution of Unix, the internet, open-source software, and so many other cool hacker ideas that echo even today.

item.title: 1 In 50 School Kids Have Autism
item.description: Health officials say the new number doesn't mean autism is occurring more often. But it does suggest that doctors are diagnosing autism more frequently, especially in children with milder problems.

item.title: Japanese Subway Stations Totally Look Like Role-Playing Game Dungeons
item.description: Recently, a Japanese net user posted a photo of the Tokyo Metro's Shibuya Station, aka "Shibuya Dungeon." For a few years now, it's been dubbed as such.

item.title: World's Strongest Coffee Has 200% More Caffeine Than Normal Cup
item.description: Overdosing on caffeine to keep your eyes from hitting the floor during your 16-hour office shift has a distinct possibility of putting you in an early grave. However, an American company has decided to embrace this by bringing out a blend of coffee named Death Wish, which it has dubbed ‘The World’s Strongest Coffee’.

item.title: Did This 911 Call Stop A School Shooting On Monday?
item.description: After noticing his roommate James Seevakumaran acting strangely and then spotting him with a gun, a University of Central Florida student called 911 from inside a locked bathroom early Monday — a call authorities say might have saved the lives of other students on campus.

item.title: Finally, Honest Hand Dryer Instructions
item.description: It's always felt like something's missing from your local public bathroom's hand dryer tutorial. Something simple, yet crucial. Something like, say, this missing third step that Doghouse Diaries has so smartly proposed.

item.title: The Untold Story Of The Women Behind The Atomic Bomb
item.description: From janitor to chemist, the women of Oak Ridge worked hard and talked little.

item.title: Where The Money Is Going In The Media Business
item.description: The Pew Research Center put out its annual State of the Media report. In it, we can see where the economic growth in media platforms is coming from.

item.title: How Barrett Brown Went From Anonymous PR To Federal Target
item.description: It started innocently enough, but Barrett Brown's exploits with and around Anonymous sucked him into a situation where he faces years in jail if convicted.

item.title: Meet Wikipedia, The Encyclopedia Anyone Can Code
item.description: It began as the encyclopedia anyone can edit. And now it’s also the encyclopedia anyone can program.

item.title: South Korea Network Attack Just 'A Virus'?
item.description: Disruption that paralysed the computer networks of broadcasters and banks in South Korea appears to have been caused by a virus..

item.title: What 420,000 Insecure Devices Reveal About Web Security
item.description: Using a simple technique, a researcher creates a benign botnet to survey the breadth of the Internet, and finds a back door flung wide open and beckoning the bad guys.

item.title: Why Are Celebrities Injecting Their Faces With Blood?
item.description: The science of the "vampire facial."

item.title: A Partial History Of Headphones
item.description: The history of headphones dates back further than the 1980s. Like many commercial electronics, modern headphones (and stereo sound) originated, in part, in the military.

item.title: McDonald’s China Offers Sausage Double Beef Burger
item.description: Similar to the Nuremburger sometimes offered at McDonald’s Germany, McDonald’s China is now serving Sausage Double Beef Burgers.

item.title: Domestic Drones Are Here, But The Law's Still Catching Up
item.description: An explosion of advanced flying vehicles is about to hit the skies, but regulation lags way behind technology.

item.title: After 'Fascist' Accusations, Ukrainian Parliament Brawls
item.description: You thought our politics were bad. If you need a fresh reminder that it could be worse: Official business at Ukraine's parliament was suspended for a short time, while MPs exchanged punches.

item.title: The Children Of Two Veterans Are Still Receiving Soldiers' Pensions
item.description: The U.S. Civil War officially ended 148 years ago this spring, and will likely be unofficially wrapping up any day now. But not quite yet. According to the AP, two children of veterans are still receiving benefits as a result of their fathers' service.

item.title: Annoyed By Radio Ads? We've Been Trying To Get Rid Of Them For 80 Years
item.description: In the early 1930s, Professor Gleason W. Kenrick of what is now Tufts University developed a machine that could be attached to a radio to automatically “delete” ads.

item.title: The Chinese Are Also Building Smart Watches And Smart Shoes
item.description: Wearable computing is not just a Made In America phenomenon. China is getting in on the act, too.

item.title: Adam Scott And 11 Other Actors Who Originally Auditioned For ‘The Office’
item.description: Rainn Wilson posted the original sign-in sheet for "The Office" auditions, and besides finding out that he tried out for the roles of both Michael Scott and Dwight Schrute, we also found out several other people who auditioned for various roles in the series.

item.title: If You Smoke, Your Grandchildren Could Pay For It
item.description: One of the first things kids used to learn in high school biology is the folly of Lamarckian evolution- the idea that environmental and behavioral forces can shape heredity. Studies like this one from however, suggest that Lamarckian thinking may not be totally wrong after all.

item.title: Cobra Takes To Kickstarter To Rebuild After Latest Foiling By G.I. Joe
item.description: Times are tough for terrorist organizations right now, especially the long suffering agents of Cobra.

item.title: How To Get Out Of Quicksand
item.description: Is it possible to survive being stuck in quicksand?

item.title: What It's Like To Write A Video Game
item.description: Modern video games are showing signs of morphing into other, still more subtle and complicated forms; among other things, they’re becoming an increasingly sophisticated vehicle for storytelling.

item.title: Building The World's Largest Ship (In 76 Seconds)
item.description: A timelapse of the construction of Maersk Line's very first Triple-E vessel at the DSME shipyard in Okpo, Korea.
